symptoms: Water-soaked streaks on leaf blades that turn yellowish-white.
Lesions start from the leaf tip and extend down the margins.
In severe cases, leaves dry up and wilt (Kresek phase).
Milky bacterial ooze may appear on lesions in the morning.
cure: Drain the field to reduce humidity.
Apply Copper Oxychloride or Streptocycline sprays.
Use biological control agents like Pseudomonas fluorescens.
prevention: Use resistant rice varieties (e.g., IR20, TKM 6).
Maintain proper field sanitation and weed control.
Seed treatment with bleaching powder and zinc sulfate.

symptoms: Oval or circular dark brown spots with a yellow halo.
Spots are evenly distributed over the leaf surface.
Grain discoloration leads to poor quality.
Severe infection causes leaves to dry out and die.
cure: Apply fungicides like Mancozeb or Carbendazim.
Spray Edifenphos or Chitosan as recommended.
Improve soil health with potassium and silicon amendments.
prevention: Treat seeds with hot water (53-54Â°C) for 10-12 minutes.
Apply balanced fertilizers; correct soil nutrient deficiencies (especially Silicon).
Remove alternate hosts and crop debris.

symptoms: Diamond or spindle-shaped lesions with gray/white centers and brown margins.
Lesions can coalesce to kill the entire leaf.
Can affect nodes and necks (Node Blast / Neck Blast).
Stunted plant growth.
cure: Spray Tricyclazole (Beam) or Isoprothiolane immediately upon symptom appearance.
Maintain water level in the field.
prevention: Balance nitrogen application; split nitrogen doses.

symptoms: Zonate lesions starting at leaf tips or margins.
Lesions appear water-soaked with alternating light and dark bands (scalded appearance).
Affected areas dry out and turn light brown.
Significant leaf area loss affecting photosynthesis.
cure: Foliar spray of Carbendazim or Benomyl.
prevention: Maintain wider spacing between plants to lower humidity.
Remove weed hosts from the field bunds.

symptoms: Oval or irregular greenish-gray spots on the leaf sheath near the water line.
Lesions enlarge and coalesce, looking like a snake skin pattern.
Infection spreads upward to leaf blades.
Poor grain filling and lodging of plants.
cure: Drain water from the field for a few days.

symptoms: Leaves are uniform green without spots or streaks.
Plants show vigorous growth and proper tillering.
No signs of wilting or discoloration.
prevention: Monitor regularly for early signs of pests or diseases.
Ensure proper water and nutrient management.
